query: What actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Several actions can be taken to mitigate the impacts of roads on amphibian populations. Road closures during seasonal amphibian migration are effective, with two studies in Germany finding that large numbers of amphibians were protected from death during breeding migrations at road closure sites and at road closure sites with assisted crossings and barrier fences (Action 842). Installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings is a widely studied approach, with six of seven studies finding that they significantly decreased amphibian road deaths, though in one study this was only effective when barrier fencing was also installed (Action 884). The effectiveness of culverts depends on design factors including diameter (wider culverts used more), substrate (natural substrates used more), and lighting effects (Action 884). Installing barrier fencing along roads is effective when combined with culverts, with seven of eight studies finding that barrier fencing with culverts decreased amphibian road deaths (Action 756). Barriers need to be at least 0.6 m high to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing over, though some species like treefrogs and 10% of common toads can still climb over barriers (Action 756). Human-assisted migration across roads is practiced extensively, with studies finding that large numbers of amphibians were moved across roads by patrols, ranging from 7,532 toads to half a million moved during breeding migrations annually (Action 784). However, despite human assistance, 64-70% of populations still declined over 6-10 years and over 500 toads were still killed on some roads (Action 784). Warning signage for motorists has limited effectiveness, with one study finding that despite warning signs and human assistance, over 500 toads were still killed on some roads (Action 841). Installing overpasses over roads/railways has been studied primarily for reptiles, with limited specific information on amphibians (Action 3510).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty-two studies investigated the effectiveness of installing culverts or tunnels as road crossings for amphibians.
Six of seven studies (including three replicated studies) in Canada, Germany, Italy, Hungary and the USA found that installing culverts or tunnels significantly decreased amphibian road deaths; in one study this was the case only when barrier fencing was also installed. One found no effect on road deaths.
Fifteen of 24 studies (including one review and 17 replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that culverts/tunnels were used by amphibians, by 15–85% of amphibians or 3–15 species, or that 23–100% of culverts or tunnels were used by amphibians or used in 12 of 14 studies reviewed. The majority of culverts/tunnels had barrier fencing to guide amphibians to entrances. Four found mixed effects depending on species, or for toads depending on the site or culvert type. Five found that culverts were used by less than 10% of amphibians or were not used. The use of culverts/tunnels was affected by diameter in three of six studies, with wider culverts used more, length in one of two studies, with long culverts avoided, lighting in all three studies, with mixed effects, substrate in three of six studies, with natural substrates used more, presence of water in two of three studies, with mixed effects, entrance location in one and tunnel climate in one study.
Six studies (including one replicated, controlled study) in Canada, Spain, the Netherlands and USA investigated the use of culverts with flowing water and found that they were used by amphibians, or rarely used by salamanders or not used, and were used more or the same amount as dry culverts.
Certain culvert designs were not suitable for amphibians; one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality of common toads and condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations. One study found that thousands of amphibians were still killed on the road."
}

Five studies evaluated the effects of installing overpasses over roads/railways on reptile populations. Three studies were in Spain, one was a review of studies in Australia, Europe and North America and one study was in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Community composition (1 study): One before-and-after, site comparison study in Australia found that the composition of reptile species on a vegetated overpass was more similar to woodland on one side of the overpass than the other.
Richness/diversity (1 study): One before-and-after, site comparison study in Australia found that a vegetated overpass was colonised by two reptile species each year over five years.

POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Occupancy/range (1 study): One before-and-after, site comparison study in Australia found that a vegetated overpass was colonized by 14 of 23 native reptile species and one non-native reptile species.

BEHAVIOUR (4 STUDIES)

Use (4 studies): Three of four studies (including two replicated studies and one review) in Spain and Australia, Europe and North America found that overpasses not designed for wildlife were used by lizards and snakes and reptiles. The other study found that overpasses not designed for wildlife were not used by snakes or lizards. Two replicated studies in Spain found that wildlife overpasses were used by lizards and Ophidians (snakes and legless lizards), and one review in Australia, Europe and North America found that one of 10 wildlife overpasses were used by reptiles. One review of road crossing structures in Australia, Europe and North America found that a rope bridge was not used by reptiles."

Sixteen studies evaluated the effects of installing barriers and crossing structures along roads/railways on reptile populations. Five studies were in the USA, three were in each of Spain, Australia and Canada and one was in each of France and South Africa.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (8 STUDIES)

Survival (8 studies): Four of seven studies (including one randomized, controlled, before-and-after study and one review) in the USA, Australia, Canada and South Africa found that installing fencing and crossing structures did not reduce road mortalities of reptiles, and in one case the percentage of mortalities may have increased. Two studies found that areas with fencing and crossing structures had fewer road mortalities of turtles and overall reptiles. One study found that reptile road mortalities still occurred in in areas with roadside barrier walls and culverts. One replicated, before-and-after study in Canada found that following installation of tunnels and guide fencing, along with signs for motorists, there were fewer road mortalities of eastern massasauga rattlesnakes.

BEHAVIOUR (12 STUDIES)

Use (12 studies): Six studies (including two replicated studies and one review) in Spain, France, the USA and Australia found that crossing structures with fencing that were not specifically designed for wildlife were used by lizards, snakes, tortoises, turtles and alligators and ophidians. One study also found that the addition of fencing around crossing structures did not affect the number of reptile crossings. Three studies (including one replicated and one before-and-after study and one review) in the USA and Spain found that wildlife crossing structures with fencing were used by gopher tortoises and 12 snake species, American alligators and lacertid lizards. One study also found that an American alligator did not use the wildlife crossing structure. Two before-and-after studies (including one controlled study) in Canada found mixed effects of installing roadside fencing and culverts on road use by turtles and snakes. One replicated study in Spain found that use of different crossing structures depended on species group. One replicated study in Australia found that reptiles used wildlife underpasses or culverts for only 1% of road crossings. One replicated, before-and-after study in Canada found that following installation of tunnels and guide fencing, along with signs for motorists, fewer eastern massasauga rattlesnakes were found crossing the road."
}

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-five studies evaluated the effects on mammals of installing tunnels, culverts or underpass under roads. COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (3 STUDIES)

Survival (3 studies): A study in South Korea found that road sections with higher underpass density did not have fewer wildlife-vehicle collisions. A review found that most studies recorded no evidence of predation of mammals using crossings under roads. A controlled, before-and-after, site comparison study in Australia found that overwinter survival of mountain pygmy-possums increased after an artificial rocky corridor, which included two underpasses, was installed.

BEHAVIOUR (23 STUDIES)

Use (23 studies): Seventeen of 20 studies (including seven replicated studies and two reviews), in the USA, Canada, Australia, Spain, the Netherlands, and across multiple continents, found that crossing structures beneath roads were used by mammals whilst two studies found mixed results depending on species and one study found that culverts were rarely used as crossings by mammals. One of the studies found that crossing structures were used by two of four species more than expected compared to their movements through adjacent habitats. A controlled, before-and-after, site comparison study in Australia found that an artificial rocky corridor, which included two underpasses, was used by mountain pygmy-possums. A replicated study in Germany found that use of tunnels by fallow deer was affected by tunnel colour and design. A study in the USA found that a range of mammals used culverts, including those with shelves fastened to the sides.
Behaviour change (1 study): A controlled, before-and-after, site comparison study in Australia found that after an artificial rocky corridor, which included two underpasses, was installed, dispersal of mountain pygmy-possums increased."
}

query: How do different partial harvesting methods in USA forests compare to clearcutting in their impact on salamander populations?
relevant_summary: A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest methods, which included harvesting groups or individual trees, thinning and shelterwood harvesting, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (Action 844, 851, 852). Specifically, three studies in the USA found that compared to clearcutting, harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance (Action 844). Similarly, three studies in the USA found that compared to clearcutting, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance (Action 851). Four studies in the USA that compared amphibians in thinned versus clearcut forest found higher amphibian abundance (apart from ensatina salamanders) or less negative overall response in thinned forest, while two found mixed effects on abundance depending on species, life stage and time since harvest (Action 852). However, all partial harvesting methods still had negative impacts compared to no harvesting. Two studies found that harvesting trees in small groups significantly decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition compared to no harvesting (Action 844). Two of three studies found that shelterwood harvesting decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition compared to no harvesting, though one found no effect (Action 851). Regarding thinning, five studies comparing thinned to unharvested forest showed mixed results - two found mixed effects depending on species and time, one found increased abundance except for ensatina salamanders, one found negative overall response, and one found no effect on abundance (Action 852).

query: What are the potential benefits and harms of controlling fish populations to protect amphibians?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, controlling fish populations to protect amphibians shows several potential benefits and harms:

**Benefits:**
Fish removal using rotenone increased numbers of amphibian species, abundance and recruitment or newt populations in studies from Sweden, the UK and USA (Action 828). Fish control including rotenone use increased breeding success for four amphibian species according to a review from Australia, the UK and USA (Action 828). Removing fish by catching significantly increased abundance of salamanders or frogs and increased recruitment, survival and population growth rate of cascades frog in four studies from the USA (Action 827). Excluding fish using barriers increased weight gain of axolotls in one controlled study in Mexico (Action 829).

**Harms and Limitations:**
When rotenone was applied, many frogs died and a small number of newts showed symptoms of negative effects in studies from Pakistan and the UK (Action 828). Fish control had no significant effect on great crested newt populations, and fish remained or returned within a few years in one UK study (Action 827). Fish control did not increase green toad breeding success and fish were soon reintroduced in one Swedish study (Action 827).

query: What is the evidence for the effectiveness of engaging the public in amphibian conservation efforts in Europe and the USA?
relevant_summary: Evidence from amphibian conservation studies shows that public engagement has demonstrated measurable effectiveness across multiple dimensions. Citizen science programs engaging volunteers to collect amphibian data involved 100-10,506 volunteers and were active in 16-17 states in the USA, with volunteers undertaking 412 surveys, surveying 121-7,872 sites, swabbing almost 6,000 amphibians and submitting thousands of amphibian records (Action 760). Volunteer engagement in habitat management showed population-level benefits, with studies in Estonia and Taiwan finding that habitat management with volunteer participation increased natterjack toad and Taipei frog populations, while programs engaged between eight and 41,000 volunteers in aquatic and terrestrial habitat restoration, restoring up to 1,023 ponds or over 11,500 km² of habitat (Action 777). Public awareness campaigns demonstrated reach and impact, with studies in Estonia and the UK finding that raising public awareness, along with other interventions, increased numbers of natterjack toads and created 1,023 ponds for amphibians, while campaigns reached over 50,000 members of the public each year or trained 1,016 people at 57 events over four years (Action 831). Education programmes showed effectiveness in knowledge transfer and conservation outcomes, with studies in Germany, Mexico, Slovenia, Taiwan, Zimbabwe and the USA finding that education programmes increased amphibian knowledge of participants, and in Taiwan, education programmes about wetlands and amphibians, along with other interventions, doubled a population of Taipei frogs (Action 776). Volunteer road assistance programs demonstrated substantial engagement despite mixed conservation outcomes, with studies in Germany, the UK and Italy finding that large numbers of amphibians were moved across roads by patrols, ranging from 7,532 toads to half a million moved annually, with the UK having over 400 patrols and 71 patrols spending an average of 90 person-hours moving toads (Action 784).

query: What are the overall success rates for establishing new amphibian populations through translocation or the release of captive-bred individuals?
relevant_summary: According to comprehensive reviews and studies, amphibian translocation efforts show moderate to good success rates for establishing breeding populations. Global reviews found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations that could be assessed resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population (Action 854). For release programs specifically involving captive-bred amphibians, 41% showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations, while 29% showed some evidence of breeding and 12% showed evidence of survival following release (Action 871). Head-starting programs, where amphibians are raised from eggs and then released, demonstrated that six of 10 studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding populations or increased existing populations (Action 881). For natterjack toads specifically, translocations established breeding populations in 30-70% of cases (Action 859). Reviews indicated that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful, but success was not related to whether animals came from wild or captive sources, life-stage, continent, or reason for translocation (Action 854).

  "action_title": "Captive breeding frogs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Thirty-three studies investigated the success of breeding frogs in captivity.
Twenty-three of 33 studies, three of which were reviews and 30 replicated studies, across the world found that amphibians produced egg in captivity, in four cases by captive-bred females. Seven found mixed results, with some species of frogs or 17–50% of captive populations  reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. One found that frogs did not breed successfully in captivity and another that all breeding frogs died. Seventeen of the studies found that captive-bred frogs were raised successfully to hatching, tadpoles, froglets or adults in captivity. One found that froglet survival was low and another that three species were not successfully raised to adulthood.
Four replicated studies (including one small study) in,Canada, Fiji, Hong Kong and Italy found that 30–88% of eggs hatched or survival to metamorphosis was 75%, as froglets was 17–51% or to adults was 50–90% in captivity.
One review and four replicated studies (including two small studies) in Germany, Italy and the USA found that reproductive success of frogs in captivity depended on temperature or a simulated wet and dry season, but not on whether frogs were housed in high or low maintenance facilities. Three replicated studies (including one small study) in Germany, Australia and Canada found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature."
}

{
  "action_id": "881",
  "action_title": "Head-start amphibians for release",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-two studies head-started amphibians from eggs and monitored them after release.
Six of 10 studies (including five replicated studies) in Denmark, Spain, the UK and USA and a global review found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads. Two found mixed results with breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites. Two found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population. For five of the studies, release of captive-bred individuals, translocation or habitat management were also carried out.
Nine of 10 studies (including nine replicated studies) in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully. One found adult survival was 1–17% over four years and one found limited breeding following the release of adults.
Four replicated studies in Australia, the UK and USA found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater and time to metamorphosis shorter in head-started compared to wild animals. One replicated study in Canada found that young head-started leopard frogs were smaller than those in the wild. One replicated study in Australia found that corroboree frog tadpoles released earlier had higher survival, but metamorphosed two weeks later than those released a month later.
Three studies (including one replicated study) in the USA only provided results for head-starting in captivity. Two found that Houston toad eggs could be captive-reared to tadpoles, but only one successfully reared adults. Three studies (including two replicated studies) in Canada and the USA found that during head-starting, amphibian growth rate, size, stress levels and survival was affected by the amount of protein provided, housing density or enclosure location. query: As an alternative to direct antifungal treatment of amphibians, what environmental management actions can reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis?
relevant_summary: Environmental management actions that can help reduce the threat of chytridiomycosis include habitat and water management approaches. Adding salt to ponds has shown promise, with one study in Australia finding that following addition of salt to a pond containing the chytrid fungus, a population of green and golden bell frogs remained free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months (Action 762). Temperature manipulation of aquatic environments may also be beneficial, as four of five studies in Australia, Switzerland and the USA found that increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30–37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis (Action 770). Equipment sterilization when moving between amphibian sites is another preventive approach, though current evidence shows two studies in Switzerland and Sweden found that Virkon S disinfectant did not affect survival, mass or behaviour of common frog or common toad tadpoles or moor frog embryos or hatchlings (Action 768). Water quality improvements through creating walls or barriers to exclude pollutants showed positive effects in one controlled study in Mexico, where installing filters across canals to improve water quality and exclude fish increased weight gain in axolotls (Action 771). Reducing impact of amphibian trade may also help prevent disease spread, with one review finding that reducing trade in two frog species through legislation allowed populations to recover from over-exploitation (Action 824). Water level regulation can support overall amphibian health, as two studies in the UK found that habitat management that included maintaining pond water levels increased natterjack toad populations or maintained newt populations (Action 833).

query: When managing understory vegetation in US forests, how does the effectiveness of herbicide use compare to mechanical removal for amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Based on studies in the USA, herbicide use for understory vegetation control had negative or no effects on amphibian populations, while mechanical removal showed some positive effects. Three studies in the USA found that understory removal using herbicide had no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance (Action 778). In contrast, one randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species, but not abundance, were significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to those without (Action 781). Additionally, one study in Canada found that following logging, American toad abundance was similar and wood frogs were lower in stands with herbicide treatment and planting compared to stands left to regenerate naturally (Action 778).

query: What does the evidence suggest about the effectiveness of legal and regulatory frameworks, such as species protection laws or financial incentive schemes, for amphibian conservation?
relevant_summary: The evidence presents a mixed picture regarding the effectiveness of legal and regulatory frameworks for amphibian conservation. Three reviews (including one systematic review) in the Netherlands and UK found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development (Action 779). However, Two reviews in the UK found that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued over 10 years increased to over 600 in England and Wales (Action 779). In terms of trade regulation, one review found that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species resulted in the recovery of the over-exploited populations (Action 785), and similarly, one review found that reducing trade in two frog species through legislation allowed populations to recover from over-exploitation (Action 824). Regarding habitat protection, one replicated, site comparison study in the UK found that populations of natterjack toads were better protected at sites with a statutory level of habitat protection than those outside protected areas, while one before-and-after study in the UK found that a common frog population increased but common toads decreased following the protection of a pond during development (Action 820). Financial incentive schemes showed more positive results: three studies (including one replicated study) in Denmark, Sweden and Taiwan found that payments to farmers created amphibian breeding habitat or increased frog or toad populations, although a second study in Taiwan found that payments did not maintain green tree frog habitat (Action 818). Additionally, one replicated, site comparison study in the Netherlands found that ditches managed under agri-environment schemes had higher numbers of amphibian species and higher abundance than those managed conventionally (Action 818).

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of livestock grazing on agricultural lands for amphibian habitats and populations?
relevant_summary: Studies have documented both benefits and negative impacts of livestock grazing on amphibian habitats and populations. Regarding benefits, habitat management that included reintroduction of grazing was found to increase green toad populations and maintain or increase natterjack toad populations and common toad populations (Action 780). Some amphibian species showed higher abundance in grazed areas, with bog turtles being less abundant in ungrazed sites compared to grazed sites, and juvenile box turtles being present less frequently in ungrazed sites (Action 3512). Green frogs and American toads were found to have higher abundance with grazing (Action 746). Grazing can be beneficial for breeding habitat, as bog turtle nests were laid only in areas that had been grazed in the current or previous growing season, and after grazing cattle to restore bog turtle habitat, more bog turtle eggs were laid and hatching success was higher (Action 3711). However, negative impacts have also been documented. Grazed plots did not have higher abundance of natterjack toads than ungrazed plots and had lower abundance of common toads (Action 780). Excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase numbers of amphibian species or overall abundance, but did increase larval abundance and abundance of green frog metamorphs (Action 746). Trampling damage was identified as a concern, with high-density spring-summer grazing resulting in fewer incidences of trampling compared to moderate-density autumn-winter grazing or low-density year-round grazing (Action 3496). Additionally, excluding cattle from ponds did not increase numbers of eggs or larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs (Action 746). The timing and intensity of grazing appears critical, as moderate density autumn-winter grazing and autumn-spring marsh flooding resulted in higher abundance of European pond turtles than high density spring-summer grazing (Action 3496).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of excluding or removing livestock from historically grazed freshwater marshes. Seven studies were in the USA, two were in Morocco and one was in Australia. In all 10 studies the focal livestock included cattle (mixed with sheep in the two studies in Morocco). Two studies in the USA were based on the same experimental set-up, and the two studies in Morocco shared some study sites.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY

Community composition (4 studies): Two site comparison studies in Morocco and the USA reported that marshes/pools fenced to exclude livestock for 3–30 years contained a different overall plant community to grazed sites. In the USA, the precise effect depended on the time since exclusion. Two replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies in marshes in Australia and the USA found that fencing to exclude cattle typically had no significant effect on the overall plant community composition after 1–14 years. One of the studies also found that the plant community in fenced and grazed marshes was of similar quality, relative to pristine local marshes.
Relative abundance (3 studies): Of three replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies that reported data on the relative abundance of plant groups, two studies (based on one experimental set-up) in the USA found that ephemeral pools fenced to exclude cattle for 1–10 years had similar or greater cover of grasses relative to forbs than pools that remained grazed. The other study, also in the USA, found that the relative abundance of forbs, grass-like plants and shrubs was similar in marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 1–3 years and marshes that remained grazed.
Overall richness/diversity (6 studies): Four replicated studies (two also randomized, paired, controlled) in the USA, Morocco and Australia found that marshes/pools fenced to exclude cattle, for 1–30 years, typically had similar overall plant species richness to sites that remained grazed. One of the studies found that the same was true for overall plant diversity. One replicated, site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years had similar (in a dry year) or greater (in a wet year) plant species richness compared to pools that remained grazed. One site comparison study in the USA found that marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 3–13 years contained fewer plant species than grazed marshes, and had similar or lower plant diversity.
Characteristic plant richness/diversity (1 study): One site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years contained a similar number of wetland-characteristic plant species to pools that remained grazed.
Native/non-target richness/diversity (3 studies): Of three replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies that reported data on native plant species richness, two studies (based on one experimental set-up) in the USA found that fencing ephemeral pools to exclude cattle for 1–10 years typically reduced native plant species richness. The other study, also in the USA, found that native plant species richness was similar in marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 1–3 years and marshes that remained grazed.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Overall abundance (3 studies): Two replicated, site comparison studies in the USA and Morocco found that ponds/pools fenced to exclude cattle for >10 years contained more vegetation than sites that remained grazed. This was measured in terms of emergent cover around pond margins or peak above-ground biomass in ephemeral pools. One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in Australia found that marshes fenced to exclude cattle for ≤4 years contained similar above-ground vegetation biomass to marshes that remained grazed.
Characteristic plant abundance (1 study): One site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that the overall abundance of wetland-characteristic plant species was greater in pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years than in pools that remained grazed.
Herb abundance (1 study): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that fencing pastures to exclude cattle typically increased herb cover in wetlands along creeks, but had no significant effect on herb cover within spring wetlands.
Individual species abundance (2 studies): Two replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies in freshwater marshes in Australia and the USA quantified the effect of this action on the abundance of individual plant species (see original papers for data).

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Visual obstruction (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that ponds fenced to exclude cattle for >10 years had greater horizontal vegetation cover, around their margins, than ponds that remained grazed.
Height (2 studies): Two replicated studies (one also randomized, paired, controlled, before-and-after) in the USA found that fencing ponds to exclude cattle, for 1–3 or >10 years, increased the height of vegetation around their margins."

query: What treatments are available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis and how effective are they?
relevant_summary: Multiple treatment approaches are available for amphibians infected with chytridiomycosis with varying effectiveness. Antifungal treatments show the most promising results - twelve of 16 studies found that antifungal treatment cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis, while four studies found treatments reduced infection levels or had mixed results (Action 882). Specifically, six of eight studies testing itraconazole found it effective at curing amphibians of chytridiomycosis, with one study showing reduced infection levels and one showing mixed effects (Action 882). However, six studies found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians (Action 882). Temperature treatment is another effective approach - four of five studies found that increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis, though one study found heat treatment at 30-35°C for 36 hours did not cure northern leopard frogs (Action 770). Antifungal skin bacteria or peptides show limited effectiveness - three of four studies found that adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin did not reduce infection rate or death, while one found it prevented infection and death (Action 764). One study found that adding antifungal skin bacteria to soil significantly reduced infection rate in red-backed salamanders, and three studies found that adding antifungal skin bacteria to infected amphibians reduced weight loss (Action 764). Treatment with antimicrobial skin peptides did not significantly increase survival in common toads (Action 764). Environmental treatments include pond salt addition, where one study found that adding salt to a pond kept green and golden bell frogs free of chytridiomycosis for at least six months (Action 762). Field treatment approaches show limited success - treating wild midwife toads with fungicide along with pond drying reduced infection levels but did not eradicate chytridiomycosis (Actions 767, 766).

query: For amphibian conservation in North America, how do the outcomes of creating new wetlands compare to restoring existing wetlands?
relevant_summary:
Based on the research evidence, both creating new wetlands and restoring existing wetlands show positive outcomes for amphibian conservation in North America, with some nuanced differences in effectiveness.

For wetland creation, five site comparison studies in the USA comparing created to natural wetlands found that created wetlands had similar numbers of amphibian species, amphibian abundance or communities depending on depth as natural wetlands (Action 880). However, two studies found that created wetlands had fewer amphibian species or lower abundance and different communities compared to natural wetlands (Action 880). One global review and two site comparison studies in the USA combined created and restored wetlands and found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance was higher or similar, or higher in 54% of studies and similar in 35% of studies reviewed compared to natural wetlands (Action 880). Five studies in Kenya and the USA found that four to 15 amphibian species used or colonized created wetlands (Action 880).

For wetland restoration, ten site comparison studies in Canada and the USA compared amphibian numbers in restored and natural wetlands, with eight finding that amphibian abundance, numbers of species and species composition were similar (Action 879). Two found that the number of species or abundance was lower and species composition different in restored wetlands (Action 879). Seven of nine studies in Canada, Taiwan and the USA found that wetland restoration increased numbers of amphibian species, with breeding populations establishing in some cases (Action 879). One global review found that in 89% of cases, restored and created wetlands had similar or higher amphibian abundance or numbers of species to natural wetlands (Action 879).

Regarding pond-specific interventions, nine site comparison studies in Australia, Canada, Spain, the UK and USA comparing created and natural ponds found that five studies showed numbers of species or breeding species were similar or higher in created ponds (Action 869). For pond restoration, six replicated before-and-after studies in Denmark, Estonia, Italy and the UK found that pond restoration and creation increased numbers of amphibian species, maintained or increased populations, or increased pond occupancy and ponds with breeding success (Action 878).

Both approaches show that success is affected by design factors, with numbers of amphibian species and abundance in created wetlands affected by wetland design, vegetation, water levels, surrounding habitat, fish presence and distance to source wetlands (Action 880), while numbers of species in restored wetlands were affected by wetland size, proximity to source ponds and seasonality, but not wetland age (Action 879).

query: What are the documented impacts of using prescribed fire on amphibian populations in US forest and grassland habitats?
relevant_summary: Based on documented studies, prescribed fire has varied impacts on amphibian populations in US forest and grassland habitats. In forest habitats, eight of 14 studies found no effect of prescribed forest fires on amphibian abundance or numbers of species, while four found mixed effects depending on species, species and year, or season of burn (Action 877). Three studies found that fires increased amphibian abundance or numbers of species, and one found that abundance decreased with fires (Action 877). Two studies found that numbers of amphibian species and abundance increased or abundance decreased with time since prescribed forest fires (Action 877). One before-and-after study found that spotted salamander hatching success increased following a prescribed forest fire (Action 877). In grassland habitats, two studies found that annual prescribed fires decreased numbers of amphibian species and abundance, or along with changes in grazing regime, increased rates of species loss (Action 862). One replicated, before-and-after study found that spring burns, but not autumn or winter burns, decreased salamander abundance (Action 862). Studies examining combined reptile and amphibian responses showed that one study found burned areas had higher combined reptile and amphibian species richness than unburned areas, while another found similar species richness and diversity between burned and unburned areas (Action 3646). In wetland contexts, one study found that burned areas had similar abundance of reptiles and amphibians compared to unburned areas (Action 3652).

query: What is the state of evidence on the effectiveness of removing various types of invasive predators to benefit native amphibians?
relevant_summary: The evidence on invasive predator removal effectiveness for native amphibians is mixed and varies by predator type. For invasive amphibian predators, removal of invasive Cuban tree frogs increased abundance of squirrel tree frogs and green tree frogs in one study (Action 822). Removing American bullfrogs significantly increased California red-legged frog populations and expanded leopard frog ranges, with California red-legged frogs found in the open twice as frequently after bullfrog removal (Action 825). For fish predators, four studies found that removing fish by catching significantly increased abundance of salamanders or frogs and increased recruitment, survival and population growth rate of cascades frog, though one UK study found fish control had no significant effect on great crested newt populations and one Swedish study found no increase in green toad breeding success (Action 827). For mammalian predators, controlling rats had no significant effect on Hochstetter's frog numbers, but survival of Maud Island frogs was significantly higher in predator-proof enclosures than in the wild, and 58% of translocated Hamilton's frogs survived the first year within predator-proof enclosures (Action 839). No evidence was found for the effectiveness of removing invasive cane toads (Action 798) or non-native crayfish (Action 797) on amphibian populations, and no evidence was captured on the effects of egg collection on American bullfrogs (Action 1047).

query: How does the success of reintroduction programs using captive-bred amphibians differ for Mallorcan midwife toads in Mallorca compared to green and golden bell frogs in Australia?
relevant_summary: The success of reintroduction programs differs significantly between Mallorcan midwife toads in Mallorca and green and golden bell frogs in Australia. For Mallorcan midwife toads, captive-bred individuals released as tadpoles, toadlets or adults established breeding populations at 38%, 80% or 100% of sites (Action 873). In contrast, green and golden bell frogs in Australia showed much lower success rates, with captive-bred frogs released mainly as tadpoles either not establishing breeding populations at all, or only establishing stable breeding populations following one of four release programmes (Action 872). Additionally, only a small proportion of captive-bred green and golden bell frogs released as tadpoles survived at least 13 months after release (Action 872). The Mallorcan midwife toad breeding program also demonstrated high survival rates, with 85% survival to metamorphosis in captivity (Action 837), though extended captive breeding (nine or more generations) resulted in slower tadpole development, reduced predator defence traits and decreased genetic diversity (Action 837).

query: In Australian captive breeding programs, how do artificial fertilization and hormone treatments compare in their success and challenges for frogs?
relevant_summary:
According to action 883, hormone treatment shows mixed success in amphibian captive breeding, with one review and nine of 10 replicated studies (including two randomized, controlled studies) in Austria, Australia, China, Latvia, Russia and the USA finding that hormone treatment of male amphibians stimulated or increased sperm production or resulted in successful breeding in captivity. However, for females, only one review and nine of 14 replicated studies found mixed results, with 30-71% of females producing viable eggs following treatment, or with egg production depending on the combination, amount or number of doses of hormones. Five studies found that eggs induced by hormone treatment were raised successfully to tadpoles, toadlets or froglets in captivity, though two studies found that most toads died before or soon after hatching.

For artificial fertilization, action 834 indicates limited success in Australian programs, with three replicated studies (including two randomized studies) in Australia and the USA finding that the success of artificial fertilization depended on the type and number of doses of hormones used to stimulate egg production. Notably, one replicated study in Australia found that 55% of eggs were fertilized artificially, but soon died, indicating early mortality as a significant challenge.

Action 835 provides broader context for Australian frog captive breeding, noting that seven studies found mixed results with some species of frogs or 17-50% of captive populations reproducing successfully in captivity, but with other species difficult to maintain or raise to adults. The study found that egg or tadpole development in captivity was affected by parental care, density or temperature in studies from Germany, Australia and Canada.

query: As an alternative to creating new ponds, what species augmentation techniques can be used to establish or increase amphibian populations at a site?
relevant_summary: Several species augmentation techniques can be used as alternatives to creating new ponds for establishing or increasing amphibian populations. Captive breeding and release programs show promise, with one review finding that 41% of release programmes of captive-bred or head-started amphibians showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations, while 29% showed some evidence of breeding and 12% showed evidence of survival following release (Action 871). Head-starting amphibians involves raising eggs, tadpoles, or juveniles in captivity before release. Six of 10 studies found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads, while nine of 10 studies found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully (Action 881). Four replicated studies found that frog survival to metamorphosis and size at metamorphosis was greater and time to metamorphosis shorter in head-started compared to wild animals (Action 881). Translocation of wild amphibians represents another viable technique, with three global reviews and one replicated study finding that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations that could be assessed resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population (Action 854). One review found that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful, but that success was not related to the source of animals (wild or captive), life-stage, continent or reason for translocation (Action 854).

query: To protect migrating amphibians, how do physical interventions like tunnels and barrier fences compare to closing roads during migration seasons?
relevant_summary: Road closure during seasonal amphibian migration has been demonstrated as effective, with two studies in Germany finding that large numbers of amphibians were protected from death during breeding migrations at road closure sites and at road closure sites with assisted crossings and barrier fences (Action 842). Physical interventions show mixed but generally positive results. For barrier fencing, seven of eight studies in Germany, Canada and the USA found that barrier fencing with culverts decreased amphibian road deaths, though effectiveness depended on fence length and material, with barriers requiring at least 0.6 m height to prevent some species from climbing over (Action 756). Tunnels and culverts demonstrated variable effectiveness, with six of seven studies in Canada, Germany, Italy, Hungary and the USA finding that installing culverts or tunnels significantly decreased amphibian road deaths, though one study found this was only effective when barrier fencing was also installed (Action 884). Tunnel and culvert usage rates varied widely, with 15 of 24 studies finding that 15-85% of amphibians or 3-15 species used these structures, with usage affected by design factors including diameter, length, lighting, substrate, water presence, and entrance location (Action 884). However, limitations exist for physical interventions - certain designs like one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality, and one study found thousands of amphibians were still killed on roads despite tunnel installation (Action 884). Some barriers had limited effectiveness, with studies finding that treefrogs and 10% of common toads climbed over barrier fencing during breeding migrations (Action 756).

query: What are the typical outcomes when creating new ponds to support toad populations in Europe?
relevant_summary: Studies from Europe show that creating new ponds for toad populations produces several typical outcomes. For natterjack toads, five before-and-after studies in the UK and Denmark found that pond creation, along with other interventions, significantly increased natterjack toad populations, or maintained or increased populations at 75% of sites (action 866). One replicated study found that created ponds had lower natterjack toad tadpole mortality from desiccation but higher mortality from predation by invertebrates compared to natural ponds (action 866). For green toads, two before-and-after studies in Denmark found that pond creation significantly increased green toad populations, while a replicated study in Sweden found that green toads used 59% and reproduced in 41% of created ponds (action 864). For toads generally, studies in Germany, the UK and USA found that toads established breeding populations in created ponds, or in one case 33% of created ponds (action 868). Studies in Denmark and Switzerland found that common toads and midwife toads naturally colonized 29-100% of created ponds, whereas captive-bred garlic toads did not colonize (action 868). A replicated study in Switzerland found that midwife toads reproduced in 16% of created ponds (action 868). One study in Denmark found that creating and restoring ponds, along with head-starting, increased populations of European fire-bellied toads (action 868). For amphibians generally, studies found that amphibians established stable populations in 50-100% of created ponds and used 64-100% and reproduced in 64-68% of created ponds (action 869).

query: What are some alternatives to clearcutting forests, and what are their documented effects on amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: Several alternatives to clearcutting forests have been studied for their effects on amphibian populations. Selective harvesting/logging involves harvesting individual trees or small groups rather than clear areas, though one study found no consistent differences between selectively harvested and clearcut stands (action 331). Shelterwood harvesting leaves some mature trees to provide shelter for regenerating forest - three studies found that compared to clearcutting, this method resulted in higher, similar or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance (action 851). A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest, which included shelterwood harvesting with three other types, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (action 851). Group harvesting involves removing trees in small clusters rather than large areas - three studies found that compared to clearcutting, harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance, and a meta-analysis found that partial harvest including this method resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (action 844). Forest thinning selectively removes some trees to reduce density - five studies comparing amphibians in thinned to unharvested forest found mixed effects depending on species and time since harvest, and a meta-analysis found that partial harvest including thinning decreased salamander populations (action 852). Four studies comparing thinned to clearcut forest found higher amphibian abundance or less negative responses in thinned forest for most species, and the meta-analysis confirmed smaller reductions in salamander populations compared to clearcutting (action 852). Patch retention involves leaving patches of unharvested trees within harvested areas, though no evidence was found for effects on amphibian populations, with one study only examining red-legged frog movement patterns (action 847).

One found a negative overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians and one found that thinning did not affect abundance. Four studies (including two replicated, controlled studies) in the USA compared amphibians in thinned to clearcut forest. Two found higher amphibian abundance, apart from ensatina salamanders, or a less negative overall response (population, physiological and behavioural) of amphibians in thinned forest. query: What are the documented benefits and potential negative impacts of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads into the wild?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, the benefits of releasing captive-bred or head-started toads into the wild include population establishment and breeding success. Two of three studies in Denmark, Sweden and the USA found that captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs established populations, in one case at 70% of sites (Action 875). For amphibians generally, six of 10 studies in Denmark, Spain, the UK and USA found that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations of frogs or toads, with mixed results showing breeding populations established in 12 of 17 studies reviewed or at two of four sites (Action 881). Nine of 10 studies in Australia, Canada, Europe and the USA found that head-started amphibians released as tadpoles, metamorphs or adults metamorphosed successfully, tended to survive the first season, winter or year or bred successfully (Action 881). One review found that 41% of release programmes of captive-bred or head-started amphibians showed evidence of breeding in the wild for multiple generations, 29% showed some evidence of breeding and 12% evidence of survival following release (Action 871).

However, potential negative impacts include population establishment failure and low survival rates. One study found that populations were not established from captive-bred and head-started toads (Action 875). Two studies in Puerto Rico found that survival of released captive-bred Puerto Rican crested toads was low and that 25% were predated within two days of release (Action 875). Two studies found that head-started metamorphs or adults did not prevent a frog population decline or establish a breeding toad population (Action 881). Captive breeding itself may have deleterious effects, with three studies finding evidence for potentially deleterious physiological or genetic changes due to captive breeding, and studies showing reduced genetic diversity in captive populations compared to wild populations (Action 599).

query: What actions can be taken to provide or improve shelter and refuge habitats for amphibians?
relevant_summary:
Several actions can be taken to provide or improve shelter and refuge habitats for amphibians. Creating artificial hibernacula or aestivation sites has shown positive results, with one replicated, before-and-after study in the UK finding that providing artificial hibernacula, along with other terrestrial habitat management, maintained populations of great crested newts (Action 759). Additionally, one replicated study in the UK found that created hibernacula were used by common frog and smooth newts, but not great crested newts, and another study found four amphibian species close to hibernacula at two of three sites (Action 759).

Creating refuges using coarse woody debris has mixed effectiveness. Two replicated, controlled studies in the USA and Indonesia found that adding coarse woody debris to forest floors had no effect on the number of amphibian species or overall abundance, but had mixed effects on abundance of individual species, while one before-and-after study in Australia found that restoration that included reintroducing coarse woody debris to the forest floor increased frog species (Action 772). One replicated, before-and-after study in the UK found that creating refugia for great crested newts, along with other interventions, maintained four populations (Action 772). Two studies in New Zealand and the USA found that artificial refugia were used by translocated Hamilton's frogs and hellbenders, although few were used for breeding (Action 772).

Regarding coarse woody debris in forests, two replicated, controlled studies in the USA found that there was no significant difference in abundance in clearcuts with woody debris retained or removed for eight of nine amphibian species, and one study found that migrating amphibians used clearcuts where woody debris was retained more than where it was removed (Action 843). One study found that within clearcut forest, survival of juvenile amphibians was significantly higher in piles of woody debris than in open areas (Action 843).

Some actions currently lack evidence, including creating refuge areas in aquatic habitats (Action 813), adding woody debris to ponds (Action 814), and encouraging aquatic plant growth as refuge against fish predation (Action 796).

query: What factors have been found to influence the success of amphibian translocation projects?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several factors have been found to influence the success of amphibian translocation projects. One review found that translocations of over 1,000 animals were more successful, indicating that larger population sizes contribute to translocation success (Action 854). However, success was not related to the source of animals (wild or captive), life-stage, continent or reason for translocation (Action 854). Overall reviews found that 35 of 54 (65%) amphibian translocations that could be assessed resulted in established breeding populations or substantial recruitment to the adult population (Action 854). For captive-bred frogs specifically, four of five studies found that those released as tadpoles, juveniles or adults established populations or stable breeding populations at 88-100% of sites (Action 870). For toad translocations, two of four studies found that translocating eggs and/or adults established common toad breeding populations, with one study finding populations established at two of four sites (Action 855). Head-starting also showed positive results, with six of 10 studies finding that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding frog populations or increased populations (Action 881).

query: In the USA, how do partial harvesting techniques like shelterwood, leave-tree, and group harvesting compare in their effects on salamander populations versus clearcutting?
relevant_summary: In the USA, studies comparing partial harvesting techniques to clearcutting show varied effects on salamander populations. A meta-analysis of 24 studies in North America found that partial harvest, which included shelterwood harvesting, group harvesting, leave-tree harvesting, and thinning, resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (actions 851, 844). Specifically for shelterwood harvesting, three studies found that compared to clearcutting, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar, or initially higher and then similar salamander abundance (action 851). For group harvesting, three studies found that compared to clearcutting, harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance (action 844). For leave-tree harvesting, two studies found that compared to clearcutting, leaving a low density of trees during harvest did not result in higher salamander abundance (action 846). For thinning, four studies comparing amphibians in thinned to clearcut forest found higher amphibian abundance or less negative overall responses in thinned forest, though with mixed effects depending on species, life stage, and time since harvest (action 852). However, when compared to unharvested forest, all partial harvesting techniques showed negative effects: shelterwood harvesting decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition (action 851), group harvesting significantly decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition (action 844), leave-tree harvesting decreased salamander abundance and changed species composition (action 846), and thinning showed mixed effects on abundance depending on amphibian species and time since harvest, with one study finding decreased populations (action 852).

query: What have been the observed effects of excluding livestock from ponds and streams on amphibian populations in the USA and UK?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence from studies in the USA and UK, the observed effects of excluding livestock from ponds and streams on amphibian populations show mixed results. In the USA, three replicated site comparison studies found that excluding livestock from streams or ponds did not increase numbers of amphibian species or overall abundance, but did increase larval abundance and abundance of green frog metamorphs (Action 746). However, two studies found that the abundance of green frogs and/or American toads was higher with grazing (Action 746). One randomized, replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that excluding cattle from ponds did not increase numbers of eggs or larval survival of Columbia spotted frogs (Action 746). Additionally, one replicated, randomized, controlled study in wet grasslands in the USA found no difference in the abundance of Yosemite toads between areas with cattle excluded and grazed areas (Actions 2319, 1417). In contrast, one before-and-after study in the UK found that pond restoration that included livestock exclusion increased pond use by breeding natterjack toads (Action 746).

  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of excluding or removing livestock from historically grazed freshwater marshes. Seven studies were in the USA, two were in Morocco and one was in Australia. In all 10 studies the focal livestock included cattle (mixed with sheep in the two studies in Morocco). Two studies in the USA were based on the same experimental set-up, and the two studies in Morocco shared some study sites.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY

Community composition (4 studies): Two site comparison studies in Morocco and the USA reported that marshes/pools fenced to exclude livestock for 3–30 years contained a different overall plant community to grazed sites. In the USA, the precise effect depended on the time since exclusion. Two replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies in marshes in Australia and the USA found that fencing to exclude cattle typically had no significant effect on the overall plant community composition after 1–14 years. One of the studies also found that the plant community in fenced and grazed marshes was of similar quality, relative to pristine local marshes.
Relative abundance (3 studies): Of three replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies that reported data on the relative abundance of plant groups, two studies (based on one experimental set-up) in the USA found that ephemeral pools fenced to exclude cattle for 1–10 years had similar or greater cover of grasses relative to forbs than pools that remained grazed. The other study, also in the USA, found that the relative abundance of forbs, grass-like plants and shrubs was similar in marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 1–3 years and marshes that remained grazed.
Overall richness/diversity (6 studies): Four replicated studies (two also randomized, paired, controlled) in the USA, Morocco and Australia found that marshes/pools fenced to exclude cattle, for 1–30 years, typically had similar overall plant species richness to sites that remained grazed. One of the studies found that the same was true for overall plant diversity. One replicated, site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years had similar (in a dry year) or greater (in a wet year) plant species richness compared to pools that remained grazed. One site comparison study in the USA found that marshes fenced to exclude cattle for 3–13 years contained fewer plant species than grazed marshes, and had similar or lower plant diversity.
Characteristic plant richness/diversity (1 study): One site comparison study of ephemeral pools in Morocco found that pools fenced to exclude livestock for >30 years contained a similar number of wetland-characteristic plant species to pools that remained grazed.
Native/non-target richness/diversity (3 studies): Of three replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies that reported data on native plant species richness, two studies (based on one experimental set-up) in the USA found that fencing ephemeral pools to exclude cattle for 1–10 years typically reduced native plant species richness. Individual species abundance (2 studies): Two replicated, randomized, paired, controlled studies in freshwater marshes in Australia and the USA quantified the effect of this action on the abundance of individual plant species (see original papers for data).

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Visual obstruction (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in the USA found that ponds fenced to exclude cattle for >10 years had greater horizontal vegetation cover, around their margins, than ponds that remained grazed.
Height (2 studies): Two replicated studies (one also randomized, paired, controlled, before-and-after) in the USA found that fencing ponds to exclude cattle, for 1–3 or >10 years, increased the height of vegetation around their margins."

query: What design and placement factors are associated with the successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several design and placement factors are associated with successful use of road tunnels by migrating amphibians. Diameter affects tunnel use, with wider culverts used more according to three of six studies (Action 884). Length is important, with long culverts avoided according to one of two studies (Action 884). Lighting affects tunnel use in all three studies that examined it, though with mixed effects (Action 884). Substrate choice is crucial, with natural substrates used more than artificial ones according to three of six studies (Action 884). The presence of water in tunnels shows mixed effects, with two of three studies finding varied results (Action 884). Entrance location affects use according to one study, and tunnel climate affects use according to one study (Action 884). The majority of successful culverts/tunnels had barrier fencing to guide amphibians to entrances, and this fencing needs to be at least 0.6 m high to prevent frogs from climbing over, though some species like treefrogs and 10% of common toads can still climb over barrier fencing during breeding migrations (Actions 884, 756). Certain designs should be avoided - one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality of common toads, and condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations (Action 884). Culverts with flowing water can be used by amphibians, though results vary by species, with some salamanders rarely using them while others use them the same amount as dry culverts (Action 884). Installing ledges in culverts can increase use - under-road culverts with ledges were used more than culverts without ledges by mammal species, and ledges with access ramps were used more often than those without (Action 2523).

query: In US forests, how do mechanical and herbicide-based methods for controlling understory vegetation compare in their effects on amphibians?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence from US forest studies, mechanical and herbicide-based methods for controlling understory vegetation show different effects on amphibians. For herbicide-based control, three studies in the USA found that understory removal using herbicide had no effect or some negative effects on amphibian abundance (Action 778). In contrast, for mechanical control methods, one randomized, replicated, controlled study in the USA found that numbers of amphibian species, but not abundance, were significantly higher in plots with mechanical understory reduction compared to those without (Action 781). This suggests that mechanical methods may be more favorable for maintaining amphibian species diversity compared to herbicide treatments, which showed neutral to negative effects on amphibian abundance in US forests.

query: What legal and regulatory actions are available to protect wild amphibian populations from threats like development and trade?
relevant_summary: Several legal and regulatory approaches exist to protect wild amphibian populations from development and trade threats. Legislative regulation can be effective for trade protection, with one review finding that legislation to reduce trade in two frog species resulted in the recovery of over-exploited populations (Action 785, 824). However, legal protection of species shows mixed effectiveness for development threats - three reviews found that legal protection of amphibian species was not effective at protecting populations during development in the Netherlands and UK, while two UK reviews found that the number of great crested newt mitigation licences issued increased to over 600 in England and Wales over 10 years (Action 779). Habitat protection measures show some promise, with one study in the UK finding that natterjack toad populations were better protected at sites with statutory habitat protection than those outside protected areas, though results were mixed for other species with common frogs increasing but common toads decreasing following pond protection during development (Action 820). Additionally, one study in South Africa found that permits issued for scientific and educational use of amphibians increased from 1987 to 1990 under legislative regulation (Action 785). For broader wildlife protection, regulating wildlife harvesting has shown some success for reptile populations, with studies showing increased population density and average size following legal protection and harvest regulations (Action 3538).

query: For natterjack toad conservation in the UK, what are the documented benefits and negative side effects of adding lime to ponds?
relevant_summary:
Based on the documented studies, adding limestone to ponds for natterjack toad conservation in the UK has shown both benefits and negative side effects. 

Benefits include: establishment of one of three translocated populations of natterjack toads (action 748), increased natterjack toad populations when combined with other species-specific habitat management (action 748), temporarily increased breeding by natterjack toads (action 748), and resulted in metamorphosis of natterjack toads at two of three sites (action 748). Additionally, limestone addition increased larval and/or egg survival in some amphibian species (action 748).

Negative side effects documented include: high tadpole mortality in natterjack toads (action 748), pond abandonment by natterjack toads (action 748), and higher numbers of abnormal common frog eggs (action 748).

query: What is the state of evidence on creating or restoring terrestrial habitat connectivity, such as through hedgerows, for amphibian populations?
relevant_summary: The evidence on creating or restoring terrestrial habitat connectivity for amphibian populations is extremely limited. One before-and-after study in Italy found that restoring connectivity between two wetlands by raising a road on a viaduct significantly decreased deaths of migrating amphibians (action 840). Additionally, one before-and-after study in Australia found that retaining native vegetation corridors maintained populations of eight of 13 frog species over 20 years (action 853). However, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of creating habitat connectivity on amphibian populations specifically (action 811). Furthermore, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of maintaining, restoring or creating habitat connectivity on farmland for mammals (action 2381), and no studies were found that evaluated the effects of restoring or creating linear habitat features/green corridors on bat populations (action 2035). No evidence was found specifically related to hedgerows for amphibian habitat connectivity.

query: To manage chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians, what are the most and least beneficial treatment strategies?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence from treatment studies, the most beneficial strategies for managing chytridiomycosis in captive amphibians are temperature treatment and antifungal treatment. Temperature treatment shows high success rates, with four of five studies finding that increasing enclosure or water temperature to 30-37°C for over 16 hours cured frogs and toads of chytridiomycosis (Action 770). Antifungal treatment is also highly effective, with twelve of 16 studies finding that antifungal treatment cured or increased survival of amphibians with chytridiomycosis, and six of eight studies testing itraconazole specifically found it effective at curing amphibians (Action 882). Antibacterial treatment shows mixed results, with chloramphenicol antibiotic treatments curing some species but trimethoprim-sulfadiazine only increasing survival time without curing blue-and-yellow poison dart frogs (Action 763). The least beneficial strategies include immunization, which showed no significant reduction in infection rate or mortality in mountain yellow-legged frogs when vaccinated with formalin-killed chytrid fungus (Action 765), and antifungal skin bacteria or peptides, where three of four studies found no reduction in infection rate or death when adding antifungal bacteria to amphibian skin (Action 764). However, antifungal treatments carry risks, as six studies found that specific fungicides caused death or other negative side effects in amphibians (Action 882).

query: What are the general outcomes of releasing captive-bred toads, including species like the Mallorcan midwife toad?
relevant_summary:
Studies on releasing captive-bred toads show varied but generally positive outcomes for establishing breeding populations. For Mallorcan midwife toads specifically, three studies found that captive-bred individuals released as tadpoles, toadlets or adults established breeding populations at 38%, 80% or 100% of sites respectively (Action 873). However, one study found that while predator defences were maintained, genetic diversity was reduced in captive-bred reintroduced populations, and toads bred in captivity for nine or more generations showed slower tadpole development, reduction in predator defence traits and decreased genetic diversity (Actions 873, 837).

For other toad species, two of three studies found that captive-bred toads released as tadpoles, juveniles or metamorphs established populations, with success rates of 70% at some sites (Action 875). However, outcomes varied significantly by species - studies of Puerto Rican crested toads found low survival rates with 25% predated within two days of release (Action 875). Head-starting programs showed more positive results, with six of 10 studies finding that released head-started tadpoles, metamorphs or juveniles established breeding populations or increased existing populations (Action 881).

Captive breeding success rates also varied by species and conditions. Ten studies found that various toad species produced eggs successfully in captivity, with eight successfully raising captive-bred toads to tadpoles, toadlets or adults, though two found that most toads died after hatching or metamorphosis (Action 848). For harlequin toads, breeding success was more challenging, with only three of five studies achieving reproduction in captivity (Action 836). Environmental factors significantly affected outcomes, with reproductive success influenced by tank humidity and outdoor enclosures showing higher success rates than indoor tanks (Action 848).

query: For road mitigation projects, what design factors are associated with the success or failure of tunnels and culverts for amphibian passage?
relevant_summary:
Based on studies of road mitigation projects, several design factors are associated with the success or failure of tunnels and culverts for amphibian passage. Diameter significantly affects usage, with wider culverts used more in three of six studies (Action 884). Length impacts effectiveness, with long culverts avoided in one of two studies (Action 884). Lighting shows mixed effects across all three studies examining this factor (Action 884). Substrate type influences usage, with natural substrates used more than artificial ones in three of six studies (Action 884). The presence of water has mixed effects in two of three studies (Action 884). Entrance location affects usage patterns in one study, and tunnel climate influences usage in one study (Action 884). 

Barrier fencing is crucial for guiding amphibians to entrances, as the majority of effective culverts/tunnels had barrier fencing, and one study found decreased road deaths only when barrier fencing was also installed (Action 884). Barriers must be at least 0.6 m high to prevent green frogs and leopard frogs from climbing over (Action 756). However, some amphibians like treefrogs and 10% of common toads can still climb over barrier fencing during breeding migrations (Action 756).

Certain design features result in failure: one-way tunnels with vertical entry chutes resulted in high mortality of common toads, and condensation deposits from steel culverts had very high metal concentrations (Action 884). Studies of culverts with flowing water show mixed results, with some being used by amphibians and others rarely used or not used at all (Action 884). Despite mitigation efforts, one study found that thousands of amphibians were still killed on roads even with culverts installed (Action 884).
